He then catches a $160 \mathrm{~g}$ puck flying at speed $\langle 40, 20, 2 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ ($z$-axis is vertical).

What is the momentum of the player before he catches the puck?

A $70 \mathrm{~kg}$ hockey player is sliding freely on his knees (no friction) on a horizontal icy surface with velocity $\langle -10, 0, 0 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. He then catches a $160 \mathrm{~g}$ puck flying at speed $\langle 40, 20, 2 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ ($z$-axis is vertical).

What is the velocity of the player after he catches the puck? Note that the guy still slides along horizontal surface of the ice.

A $70 \mathrm{~kg}$ hockey player is sliding freely on his knees (no friction) on a horizontal icy surface with velocity $\langle -10, 0, 0 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. He then catches a $160 \mathrm{~g}$ puck flying at speed $\langle 40, 20, 2 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ ($z$-axis is vertical).

What is the change in the momentum of the guy?

A $70 \mathrm{~kg}$ hockey player is sliding freely on his knees (no friction) on a horizontal icy surface with velocity $\langle -10, 0, 0 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. He then catches a $160 \mathrm{~g}$ puck flying at speed $\langle 40, 20, 2 \rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ ($z$-axis is vertical).

What is the change in the momentum of the puck?

An unstable Pu-240 nucleus (mass $240.002 \mathrm{~u}$) is at rest when it fissions into two Ag-120 nuclei (mass $119.893 \mathrm{~u}$) which then fly off far from each other. Find the final kinetic energy of one Ag-120 nucleus when it is far from the other one. $\left(1 \mathrm{~u}=1\right.$ atomic mass unit $\left.=1.66 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\right)$

When a falling object reaches terminal speed, its kinetic energy reaches a constant value. However, the gravitational potential energy of the system consisting of the object, Earth and atmosphere continues to decrease. Which of the following best describes why this is not a violation of the conservation of energy for the system consisting of the object plus the Earth?

choices.answer: The air increases in temperature due to internal work done on the air molecules, $W$.
The small number of nuclear decays within the object decreases the rest mass of the falling object.
The chemical energy of the object increases in order to compensate for the decrease in gravitational potential energy.
The air increases in temperature due to heat exchange, $Q$.
The Earth's kinetic energy increases in order to compensate for the decrease in potential energy.

questions.question: A block of mass $10 \mathrm{~kg}$ is being pulled across the floor at constant velocity by a rope. The tension in the rope is $20 \mathrm{~N}$ and the rope is at an angle of $25\degree$ above the horizontal. Find the force that the floor exerts on the block. ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/w3vT5IUenilK0HZMSHhbz)

A proton and an electron are far apart at rest. An external agent brings the electron and proton closer together and then holds them at rest. Which statement is correct about the work done by the external agent?

choices.answer: The work done in this case is zero because the proton and the electron will spontaneously come close to each other even without any external force.

questions.question: A car is about to make a turn at $v=3 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ such that the radius of the kissing circle at the turn is $10 \mathrm{~m}$. What should the minimum coefficient of friction be so that the car does not slip on the road?

choices.answer: One must know the mass of the car to answer the question.

questions.question: $110$ grams of boiling water are poured into an aluminum pan whose mass is $1000$ grams. The initial temperature of the water is $100 \degree \mathrm{C}$, with a heat capacity of $4.2 \frac{J}{gram \cdot K}$. The aluminum plan has an initial temperature of $24 \degree \mathrm{C}$ with a heat capacity of $0.9\frac{J}{gram \cdot K}$. After a while, the water and pan come to a common temperature. What is that temperature?

The figure below is a graph of the energy of a system of a planet interacting with a star. The gravitational potential energy $\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{g}}$ is shown as the thick curve, and plotted along the vertical axis are various values of $\mathrm{K}+\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{g}}$. Suppose that $\mathrm{K}+\mathrm{U}_{\mathrm{g}}$ of the system is $\mathrm{A}$. Find all of the true statements below.

1. The potential energy of the system decreases as the planet moves from $\mathrm{r}_{1}$ to $\mathrm{r}_{2}$. 
2. The potential energy of the system increases as the planet moves from $\mathrm{r}_{1}$ to $\mathrm{r}_{2}$. 
3. When the separation between the two bodies is $\mathrm{r}_{2}$, the kinetic energy of the system is $\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{B}$. 
4. The system is a bound system; the planet can never escape.
5. The path traced by this orbiting system is a circle. 
6. When the separation between the two bodies is $\mathrm{r}_{1}$, the kinetic energy of the system is $\mathrm{B}-\mathrm{C}$.

 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/t2bsIUIL8K0Rr-SSjY0J2)

Starting from each of the locations, A-F, the comet advances in the next instant along its orbit. What is the sign of the work done on the comet by the star at different points in the orbit?
 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/qQnAQ3Hr5Flyaoe9Tx74i)

choices.answer: No work is done on the comet by the star

questions.question:
A Ferris wheel is a vertical, circular amusement ride with radius, $R=\mathbf{1 0} \mathrm{m}$. Riders sit on seats that swivel to remain horizontal. The Ferris wheel rotates so that riders move at a constant speed, $v=5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. Consider a rider whose mass, $m=\mathbf{6 0} \mathrm{kg}$. Assume that the acceleration due to gravity, $g=\mathbf{1 0} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$.

How much work does the force exerted by the seat do on the rider as they move from point $H$ to point $B$ ? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/wkoHeYj6CV7qkVzOkA-GZ)

choices.answer: None of the above, because the rider's speed does not change.

questions.question:
A space craft, mass $100 \mathrm{~kg}$ is in outer space at location $\langle1,2,5\rangle \mathrm{~m}$ moving at an initial speed of $2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$. One set of thrusters are now turned on and exert a constant force $\langle -100,200,0 \rangle \mathrm{~N}$ until the object reaches location $\langle 2,3,5 \rangle \mathrm{~m}$. At this point, these thrusters are turned off, and another set of thrusters are turned on which exert a constant force $\langle 200,-100,0 \rangle \mathrm{~N}$ until the space craft reaches $\langle 5,4,5 \rangle \mathrm{~m}$.

What is the speed of the space craft at the final location?

An ice block of mass $m$ is initially at rest at location $1$ on a smooth semicircular track in a vertical plane. A little later it is sliding through location $2$.

What is the speed, $v$ of the ice block at location $2$ ?
 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/X3IvrbNV16AkKq51GlwLL)

An ice block of mass $m$ is initially at rest at location $1$ on a smooth semicircular track in a vertical plane. A little later it is sliding through location $2$.

What is the magnitude of the normal force, $F_{N}$ exerted on the block by the ice surface at point $2$?
 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/ddF2uxedpqgzo-gvT_heK)

A radioactive nucleus of mass $M_{1}$ is at rest when it decays into an alpha particle (He-4 nucleus), mass $M_{\alpha}$, and a new nucleus, mass $M_{2}$. When the alpha particle and the new nucleus have moved far away from each other (so that the electric potential energy of the final alpha-nucleus system is negligible),

Which of the following represents the sum of the kinetic energies of the alpha particle and the new nucleus?

The figure below is a graph of the energy of a system consisting of a planet interacting with a star. The gravitational potential energy $U$ is shown as the thick curve. The thick horizontal lines represent $K$ + $U$. Suppose that when distance from the star to the planet is $r_{1}$, $K$ + $U$ = $A$. Find ALL of the TRUE statements from among statements 1 through 5 below.

1. $K$ decreases as the distance from star to planet changes from $r_{1}$to $r_{2}$
2. $K$ increases as the distance from star to planet changes from $r_{1}$ to $r_{2}$
3. When the distance from star to planet is $r_{2}$, $K$ = $A$  $B$. 
4. The system is a bound system; the planet can never escape. 
5. When the distance from star to planet is $r_{1}$, $K$ = $B$  $C$. ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/aBJFjHB5_zag0QqESDVTA)

Three protons, each of mass $\boldsymbol{m}$ and charge $+\boldsymbol{e}$, are initially held at the corners of a triangle that is $\boldsymbol{d}$ on a side. They are then released from rest.

Which of the following equations will you need to solve to determine the speed $v$ of each proton, when the protons are very far apart?

An object attached to a spring oscillates back and forth on an incline plane. The x-axis is parallel to the incline plane. The equilibrium position is $x$ = 0, and the positive x-axis is in the direction of stretching. At $t$ = 0, the object is released from the compressed spring position. 
Which graphs represents the position, $x$($t$) and velocity, $v_{x}$($t$) of the object?

A motionless light vertical hanging spring, stiffness constant $k_{S}$ has a relaxed length, $L_{0}$. A mass, $M$ is attached to the end of the spring and comes to equilibrium. With the mass and spring at rest, you very slowly pull down on the mass so that the spring stretches an additional length, $s_{i}$. At that point, you give the mass an upward initial speed, $v_{i}$.

Which of the following equations will you need to solve to determine the maximum compression, $s_{max}$, of the spring relative to the equilibrium position? Consider the spring, 
mass and Earth as the system. ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/SMnwFInn8GxQ_cXwVVIw-)

Starting from rest, a woman lifts a barbell of mass $\boldsymbol{m}$ with a constant force of $\boldsymbol{F}$ Newtons through a distance of $\boldsymbol{h}$ meters, at which point she is still lifting, and the barbell has acquired a speed of $\boldsymbol{v} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$.

Let $E_{\text {woman }}$ stand for the internal energy of the woman.

For the system consisting of the woman + barbell + Earth, which equation below is the correct application of the energy principle from the initial state with the barbell at rest to the final state with the barbell having moved upward a distance $\boldsymbol{h}$ and has a speed $\boldsymbol{v}$ ?

choices.answer: $\Delta E_{\text {woman }}+\left(\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}-0\right)+(m g h-0)=F h$
$\Delta E_{\text {woman }}+\left(0-\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}\right)+(0-m g h)=F h$

questions.question:
A block of mass $M_{A}$ and specific heat $C_{A}$ has an initial temperature of $T_{A}$. It is brought into thermal contact with a second block of mass $M_{B}$ and specific heat $C_{B}$ at temperature $T_{B}$.

Which equation should you solve to find the final equilibrium temperature $T$ ?

In a rough attempt to repeat Joule's famous experiment you begin with $1 \mathrm{~k g}$ of water at room temperature in a not very well insulated container. You stir the water until a thermometer shows that its temperature increased by $ 1 \mathrm{~K}$. In the process you did $5000 \mathrm{~J}$ of work on the water by stirring it.

What is the magnitude of the energy transfer, $|{Q}|$, from the water to its surroundings due to a temperature difference that occurred while you stirred? Note: the specific heat capacity of water is $4200 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{K}$.

A perfectly insulated house has a volume of $500 \mathrm{~m}^{3}$ and air temperature $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. You bring in a closed bucket of $10 \mathrm{~kg}$ water at almost $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

What will the approximate temperature be in the house after equilibration?

Use specific heat of water $=4200 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{K} / \mathrm{kg}$, specific heat of air $=1000 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{K} / \mathrm{kg}$, and density of air = $1.2 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$.

A single falling coffee filter quickly reaches a constant terminal speed. At this speed, how does the magnitude of the force due to air resistance, $\left|\vec{F}_{\text {air }}\right|$ compare with the magnitude of the force due to gravity, $\left|\vec{F}_{\text {grav }}\right|$ ?

choices.answer: The answer depends on other factors not provided

questions.question:
A spring of stiffness, $k_{s}$ and un-stretched length, $L_{0}$ is placed vertically on a horizontal surface. A block of mass $M$ is initially held at rest pressing down on the  top of the spring, such that the compressed length of the spring is $L$. The block is in contact with, but not attached to the spring, so when you release the block, the spring pushes it up all the way to the top of the top of the un-stretched length of the spring, at which point it is launched into the air.

Three students present statements about how to find the speed $v_{0}$ at which the block is launched into the air at the top of the spring. Which is correct?

Amy: You choose the block as the system and Earth and spring as the surroundings and your equation is: $\left(\frac{1}{2} M v_{0}^{2}-0\right)=-M g\left(L_{0}-L\right)+\frac{1}{2} k_{s}\left(L_{0}-L\right)^{2}$

Beth: You choose the block and spring as the system and Earth as the surroundings and your equation is : $\left(\frac{1}{2} M v_{0}^{2}-0\right)+\left(0-\frac{1}{2} k_{s}\left(L_{0}-L\right)^{2}\right)=-M g\left(L_{0}-L\right)$

Cathy: You choose the block, spring, and Earth in the system, and nothing in the surroundings, then your equation is: $\left(\frac{1}{2} M v_{0}^{2}-0\right)+M g\left(L_{0}-L\right)=\frac{1}{2} k_{s}\left(L_{0}-L\right)^{2}$ ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/UFk92bI4GjZ5uOJjjlvWK)

choices.answer: Amy is correct, but Beth and Cathy are wrong.
Beth is correct, but Amy and Cathy are wrong.
Cathy is correct, but Amy and Beth are wrong.
Both Amy and Beth are correct, Cathy is wrong.

questions.question:
A spring of stiffness, $k_{s}$ and un-stretched length, $L_{0}$ is placed vertically on a horizontal surface. A block of mass $M$ is initially held at rest pressing down on the  top of the spring, such that the compressed length of the spring is $L$. The block is in contact with, but not attached to the spring, so when you release the block, the spring pushes it up all the way to the top of the top of the un-stretched length of the spring, at which point it is launched into the air.

What is the maximum height, $h_{\max }$ (relative to the top of the uncompressed spring) achieved by the block before it starts to come down again?

A spring of stiffness, $k_{s}$ and un-stretched length, $L_{0}$ is placed vertically on a horizontal surface. A block of mass $M$ is initially held at rest pressing down on the  top of the spring, such that the compressed length of the spring is $L$. The block is in contact with, but not attached to the spring, so when you release the block, the spring pushes it up all the way to the top of the top of the un-stretched length of the spring, at which point it is launched into the air.

What is the time $t_{\max }$ after it is launched, for the block to reach the highest point on its flight?

Your friend, mass $m$ jumps up from a crouched position to a vertical standing position, such that their center of mass moves vertically upward through height $h$. During this process, the point of contact between your friends feet and the ground is stationary. Your friend experiences a normal force $F_{n}$ acting upward at the point of contact between the feet and the ground. Your friends change in internal energy in the 
process is $\Delta E_{int}$ and their change in kinetic energy due to their torso moving relative to the center of mass is $\Delta K_{rel}$

Which of the following equations represents the energy principle of the point particle system as applied to your friend from the initial to the final positions shown above? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/WgPKvwudItKQk_GIbiwOI)

Your friend, mass $m$ jumps up from a crouched position to a vertical standing position, such that their center of mass moves vertically upward through height $h$. During this process, the point of contact between your friends feet and the ground is stationary. Your friend experiences a normal force $F_{n}$ acting upward at the point of contact between the feet and the ground. Your friends change in internal energy in the 
process is $\Delta E_{int}$ and their change in kinetic energy due to their torso moving relative to the center of mass is $\Delta K_{rel}$

Which of the following equations represents the energy principle of the extended system as applied to your friend from the initial to the final positions shown above? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/T6SpSHUZ9-v1noqo1HTrc)

You, mass $M$ hang by your hands from a tree limb that is a height $L$ above the ground, with your center of mass a height $h$ above the ground, and your feet a height $d$ above the ground. You then let yourself fall. You absorb the shock by bending your knees, ending up momentarily at rest in a crouched position with your center of mass a height $b$ above the ground.

What is your kinetic energy at the instant your feet first touch the ground?

You, mass $M$ hang by your hands from a tree limb that is a height $L$ above the ground, with your center of mass a height $h$ above the ground, and your feet a height $d$ above the ground. You then let yourself fall. You absorb the shock by bending your knees, ending up momentarily at rest in a crouched position with your center of mass a height $b$ above the ground.

What is the change in internal energy in your body from the initial to final position? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/5Mkp26KBRGrZq-JQW9U32)

Using a string, you pull a $2.0-\mathrm{kg}$ box along a nearly frictionless table with a constant force of $100 \mathrm{~N}$, starting from rest. The box is full of liquid and is a cube of dimensions $1 \mathrm{~m} \times 1 \mathrm{~m} \times 1 \mathrm{~m}$. The center of mass of the system is initially located at $r_{C M i}=\langle 0.5,0.5,0\rangle \mathrm{m}$ relative to the left, lower corner of the box. At some time later, your hand has pulled through a distance of $2 \mathrm{~m}$, and the center of mass has shifted to $r_{C M f}=\langle 2.25,0.5,0\rangle$. The fluid and box is defined as "the system." There is no energy transferred thermally between the system and its surroundings.

What is the change in internal energy of the system? [Hint: You will first need to find the change in translational kinetic energy of the system.]

A rod of length $L$ and negligible mass is attached to a uniform disk of mass $M$ and radius $R$. A string is wrapped around the disk, and you pull on the string with a constant magnitude force $F$.

Two small balls each of mass $m$ slide along the rod with negligible friction. The apparatus starts from rest, and when the center of the disk has moved a distance $d$, a length of string $s$ has come off the disk, and the balls have collided with the ends of the rod and stuck there. The apparatus slides on a nearly frictionless table.

What is the angular speed, $\omega$ of the disk at this instant?

Note: The moment of inertia of a disk is $I=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$. ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/SY_BRv1dpOjBRClMrp33n)

String is wrapped around an object of mass $M$ and moment of inertia $I$. With your hand you pull the string straight up with some constant force $F$ such that the center of the object does not move up or down, but the object spins faster and faster. When your hand is a height $y_{0}$ above the floor, the object has an angular speed of $\omega_{0}$.


What is the angular speed, $\omega$ of the object, when your hand has risen to a height $y=y_{0}+$ $\Delta y$ above the floor?

Two identical masses on a frictionless surface are connected to each other with a spring. The initial and final configurations of the masses are shown in the figure. Initially, the spring is at its equilibrium length. The rightmost mass is pulled with a force $F=100 \mathrm{~N}$ to the right.

What is the change in translational kinetic energy of the system from the initial to the final position? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/usv1pjSru8dhjidg4yBbX)

Two identical masses on a frictionless surface are connected to each other with a spring. The initial and final configurations of the masses are shown in the figure. Initially, the spring is at its equilibrium length. The rightmost mass is pulled with a force $F=100 \mathrm{~N}$ to the right.

What is the change in internal energy of the system from the initial to the final position? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/BTciZMu1JX6faPWrXDhvZ)

Four objects of the same mass, $M$ are initially at rest and positioned as shown on an inclined plane of height $h$. The "particle" is a flat, slippery object that can slide down the plane without friction. The other objects, all having the same radius, $R$ are a solid cylinder, a hoop and a solid sphere that roll down the plane without slipping.

Note: 
$I_{\text {hoop }}=M R^{2}$
$I_{\text {cylinder }}=\frac{1}{2} M R^{2}$
$I_{\text {sphere }}=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2}$

If they are all released at the same time, in what order (first to last) will the objects reach the finish line? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/-MMu-p6b5UUnqK8pOKsKl)

A vehicle travels along a circular path as shown in the figure. From $A$ to $B$, the vehicle maintains a constant speed of $4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, from $B$ to $C, 8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, and from $C$ to $D, 12 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.

What is the average speed of the vehicle in traveling from $A$ to $D$ ? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q1.png)

A small space probe of mass $\mathrm{m}=1000\mathrm{~kg}$  is launched from a space station in deep space. The space station exerts negligible gravitational force on the space probe. At time $\mathrm{t}=0$ when the initial position of the space probe (relative to the space station) is $\langle100,200,0\rangle \mathrm{~m}$, and its velocity (relative to the space station) is $\langle200,300,0\rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, the spaceprobe turns on its thrusters that exert a constant force of $\langle4000,-5000,0\rangle \mathrm{~N}$.

Using a time step of $1$ second, determine the velocity of the space probe (relative to the space station) after two time steps, i.e. at $\mathrm{t}=2$ seconds.

A small space probe of mass $\mathrm{m}=1000\mathrm{~kg}$  is launched from a space station in deep space. The space station exerts negligible gravitational force on the space probe. At time $\mathrm{t}=0$ when the initial position of the space probe (relative to the space station) is $\langle100,200,0\rangle \mathrm{~m}$, and its velocity (relative to the space station) is $\langle200,300,0\rangle \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, the spaceprobe turns on its thrusters that exert a constant force of $\langle4000,-5000,0\rangle \mathrm{~N}$.

Using a time step of $1$ second, determine the position of the space probe (relative to the space station) after two time steps, i.e. at $\mathrm{t}=2$ seconds.

A hockey puck slides on ice (looking down on the ice from above); friction and air resistance are negligible. When the puck reaches location $2$ it is struck hard by a hockey stick; the contact lasts a very short time. It then travels from $2$ to $3$ at nearly constant momentum. The magnitude of the puck's momentum is the same at locations $1$ and $3$.

Which arrow (A through D) best indicates the direction of the force applied to the puck by the hockey stick? Assume the force was constant during the contact. ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q4.png)

In a crash test, a car with a mass of $1500 \mathrm{~kg}$ is initially moving at a speed of $18 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ just before it collides with a barrier. The final speed of the car after the collision is zero. The original length of the car is $4.48 \mathrm{~m}$, but after the collision, the smashed car is only $3.86 \mathrm{~m}$ long.

Making the very rough approximation that the large force that the barrier exerts on the car is approximately constant during contact, determine the approximate magnitude of this force? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q5.png)

The figure below shows two negatively charged objects (with the same charge) and one positively charged object. What is the direction of the net electric force on the positively charged object?
 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/XjHnJ8sZtR1f35grEoy84)

choices.answer: There is not enough information to answer this question

questions.question:
You kicked a ball of mass $\mathrm{m}=2\mathrm{~kg}$ that was initially at rest with a force $\vec{F}=\langle12,0,-16\rangle\mathrm{~N}$ so that the ball is now rolling on the grass field.

What is the initial velocity of the ball after the kick if the duration of the kick is $\Delta t=0.1 \mathrm{~s}$

You kicked a ball of mass $\mathrm{m}=2\mathrm{~kg}$ that was initially at rest with a force $\vec{F}=\langle12,0,-16\rangle\mathrm{~N}$ so that the ball is now rolling on the grass field.

The net force on the rolling ball acts in the direction opposite to its momentum. Which vector below is the direction of the net force acting on the rolling ball immediately after it is kicked?

A ball of mass, $\mathbf{M}$ hangs by two strings from the ceiling as shown in the figure. The acceleration due to gravity has magnitude $\mathbf{g}$, and acts vertically downward in the picture shown.

What is the magnitude of the force of tension $F_{T}$ in each of the upper strings? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q9.png)

An elevator is accelerating downward at with magnitude of acceleration $\mathbf{a}$. A block of mass $\mathbf{M}$ hangs by a low-mass rope from the ceiling of the elevator as shown. The acceleration due to gravity has magnitude $\mathbf{g}$, and acts vertically downward in the picture shown.

What is the force of tension, $\vec{F}_{T}$ in the rope?
 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q10.png)
Suppose that the period of a particular ideal mass-spring system is $4 \mathrm{~s}$. What would be the period of the system if the mass were four times the original mass?

A car traverses the course as shown, which consists of two semicircular paths, $A-B$ (radius 2R) and $\mathrm{B}-\mathrm{C}$ (radius R) as shown in the figure below. The speed of the car increases as it traverses the course, such that at point $1$ shown, its speed is $v$ and at point $2$, its speed is $2 v$ respectively.

How does the transverse component of the net force $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ on the car, compare at the two points? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q12.png)

choices.answer: $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $2$ is quarter of $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $1$.
$\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $2$ is half of $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $1$.
$\left|\vec{F}_{\text {net }, \perp}\right|$ at point $2$ is twice $\left|\vec{F}_{\text {net }, \perp}\right|$ at point $1$.
$\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $2$ is four times $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $1$.
$\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $2$ is eight times $\left|\vec{F}_{n e t, \perp}\right|$ at point $1$.

questions.question: A piece of cork (density $250 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$ ) of mass $0.01 \mathrm{~kg}$ is held in place under water (density $1000 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$ ) by a string. What is the tension, $T$, in the string? (Use $g=10$ $\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}$) ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q13.png)

A thin platinum bar is $1 \mathrm{~m}$ long with a $1 \mathrm{~mm} \times 1 \mathrm{~mm}$ cross section and is attached to the ceiling. When a $10 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass hangs from the bar it stretches $2.0 \mathrm{~mm}$. If we hang the same $10 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass from a $2 \mathrm{~m}$ long platinum bar that has a $2 \mathrm{~mm} \times 2 \mathrm{~mm}$ cross section, how much will that bar stretch?

Two boxes move together with the same acceleration across an icy surface as you push with a horizontal force of magnitude $F$, as shown below. The mass of box $1$ is $60 \mathrm{~kg}$, and the mass of box $2$ is $20 \mathrm{~kg}$.

What is the best estimate of the magnitude of the net force acting on box $1$? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q15.png)

A block of mass $m$ is attached by a spring with stiffness $k_{s}$ to a wall at the top of a slippery ramp as shown in the figure. The spring's relaxed length is $L_{0}$. At time $\mathrm{t}=0$ the spring's stretched length is L and the block's velocity is $\vec{v}_{i}$.

Which of the following is an accurate free body diagram representing the forces acting on the block?
 ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/ewk9y5YT8SCG61oLL3iJZ)
![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/KCiZFUFEx0O9kCLJkU-ib)

A block of mass $m$ is attached by a spring with stiffness $k_{s}$ to a wall at the top of a slippery ramp as shown in the figure. The spring's relaxed length is $L_{0}$. At time $\mathrm{t}=0$ the spring's stretched length is L and the block's velocity is $\vec{v}_{i}$.

The mass of the block is $m=5 \mathrm{~kg}$, the angle of the incline plane $\theta=30^{\circ}$. The spring stiffness is $k_{s}=50 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}$. The relaxed length of the spring is $L_{0}=0.5\mathrm{~m}$. The origin of the coordinate system shown is at the top of the incline plane, such that the initial position of the block is $\vec{r}_{i}=\langle -L,0,0 \rangle = \langle -0.60,0,0\rangle \mathrm{~m}$, and its initial velocity is $\vec{v}_{i} = \langle -1,0,0 \rangle \mathrm{~m}/\mathrm{s}$. Use $g = 10 \mathrm{~m}/\mathrm{s}^2$.

What is the net force acting on the block? ![](https://boilerexams-production.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/q16-19.png)

A truck driver slams on the brakes, changing the velocity of the $1000 \mathrm{~kg}$ truck from $\langle 21,0,0\rangle \mathrm{m}/\mathrm{s}$ to $\langle 5,0,0 \rangle\mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ in $2$ seconds due to a constant force of the road on the truck tires. What force was exerted by the road on the tires during this interval?
